awd_titl_txt: LTREB: Female Settlement Patterns and Social Relationships in Chimpanzees, a Male-Philopatric Species
awd_abstract_narration:
Social connectedness greatly affects human health. Investigation of the evolutionary basis of human relationships through study of factors influencing social bonding in chimpanzees, humans' closest living relatives, will reveal how and why social bonds are important. Chimpanzees, like humans, are very unusual among mammals in that males remain in their birth group, while most females join another group at adolescence. Kinship is a powerful basis for friendly bonds, but dispersing females must leave their kin and join groups of unrelated individuals, many of which are hostile to these new competitors.  This project takes advantage of the uniquely long-term field study of the Gombe chimpanzees, initiated by Jane Goodall in 1960, to examine factors influencing whether females disperse, how they integrate into a new community, the kinds of relationships they establish with other females, and how they benefit from these bonds. Results, disseminated in scientific papers, the press, film documentaries, and widely visited websites will keep these iconic chimpanzees in the public eye, and will continue to draw young people (especially women) into science. The project involves undergraduates from underrepresented groups and provides scientific training and education experience to Tanzanians. It provides crucial information for community conservation efforts around Gombe and across Africa.

In the first half of the decadal research plan, the objectives have been to compile and analyze 40 years of spatially-explicit ecological and behavioral data to identify factors influencing female distribution and social association, and to initiate collection of behavioral data on young females in three communities as they settle. In the next 5 years, the first objective is to continue data collection on maturing females to produce a sufficient sample to test the hypothesis that female settlement is based on the location of high quality resources, the density and dominance rank of resident females, and the presence of related or familiar females. The second objective is to collect detailed data on adult female behavior to test hypotheses arising from initial analyses about the nature and consequences of female relationships. Do social bonds enhance the ability to compete for resources and/or dominance via coalitionary aggression? Do bonds with other mothers benefit male offspring by promoting their interactions with male peers? Results will contribute to greater understanding of chimpanzee behavior and provide a basis from which to consider the evolution of mammalian social organization and human relationships.  Data are compiled in a relational database, stored at Duke University and available to colleagues, worldwide.

por.por_cntn:
Chimpanzees provide clues to the origins of human social bonds

Social connectedness powerfully influences human health and longevity, yet the complexities of modern society make it difficult to identify common patterns and root causes underlying differences in social bonding. Investigating the patterns of sociality in our closest living relatives can provide insight. Chimpanzees live in permanent social groups in which males stay in their birth group, while most females leave at adolescence and join another group.  Males compete for access to females within the group and form strong dominance hierarchies. However, they also form strong bonds with the other males of their group, and cooperate to defend the group range. Females are less social, to some extent avoiding competition for food with other females by feeding alone, but dominance rank is also important and high rank increases reproductive success. These sex differences in residence patterns resemble many human societies but are unusual among other mammal species, where the more common pattern is for females to stay and males to leave. Sex biased dispersal is thought to have evolved at least partly as an inbreeding avoidance mechanism. One important basis for friendly bonds is kinship. For the dispersing sex, leaving their group results in the severing of ties to their close relatives, depriving them of this source of social support.

Our broad aim in this study was to investigate the origin, form and function of social bonds in chimpanzees. We were particularly interested in the importance of kinship and other factors in the formation of bonds, and the consequences of these bonds for reproductive success. Our major focus was on females, whose lives were less understood, but we also gained further understanding of male bonding. Because chimpanzees have extremely slow life histories – they can live for over 50 years, do not reach sexual maturity until their teens, and reproduce very slowly – such questions can only be answered by observing the same population for many decades. Ten years support from the LTREB program helped us extend core data collection in the uniquely long-term study of three social groups of chimpanzees in Gombe National Park, Tanzania, initiated by Jane Goodall in 1960.

We found that social relationships with close kin were important for both sexes throughout their lives.  Although chimpanzees are weaned around the age of five, females whose mothers die before they are 10 years old, and males orphaned before the age of 15 years have lower survival, and orphaned females take longer to mature. Although most females leave their natal community around the age of 11, some females at Gombe stay. By examining the dispersal decisions of 33 females, we found that the presence of maternal brothers and the presence of their mother had opposite effects.  In accordance with the inbreeding hypothesis, females were more likely to leave the more maternal brothers they had in their natal community. But those females whose mothers were alive and high ranking were more likely to stay.  Such females continued to share their mother’s feeding areas, experienced fewer feeding competitors, entered the dominance hierarchy at higher positions, and gave birth more quickly than females without a mother in the community. As adults, females formed strong relationships with their maturing daughters if they had them. They also maintained friendly relationships and associated with their adult sons, especially in the first few months after they have given birth. Such association likely provides protection against infanticide that is perpetrated by both females and males in this population.

We found that strong social bonds with other males help adult males rise in rank and achieve higher reproductive success. Bonds were strongest between maternal siblings that were close in age. However, on average, it was relatively rare for males to have adult maternal brothers, and there were no clear predictors of close bonds between unrelated males. However, bonds forged between young males and older males tended to persist, while those between young males did not.

Data collected during the study were added to the relational database on the Gombe chimpanzees that was hosted at Duke University and now at Arizona State University. Results from the study have so far been published in dozens of scientific papers and data produced during the study facilitated many more papers by scientists from many different institutions on such subjects as maternal behavior, stress, health, disease, and the gut microbiome. These research findings garnered significant press coverage and were disseminated on widely visited websites.  By keeping these iconic chimpanzees in the public eye, the Gombe study has continued to draw young people (especially women) into science. The project involved undergraduates from underrepresented groups and provided employment and education to Tanzanians. Its results on resource distribution, chimpanzee dispersal, ranging patterns and disease provide crucial information for community conservation efforts around Gombe and across Africa.
